frontmatter.title: A peek at numerical methods for diffusion models

abbreviations.EMIC: Earth System Model of Intermediate Complexity

children.label: 1. The one-dimensional diffusion equation

children.html: u(x)u(x)u(x)

children.value: is mixed down-gradient by a diffusive process.

children.html: F=−K∂u∂xF = - K \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}F=−K∂x∂u​

children.value: There will be local changes in

children.html: uuu

children.value: wherever this flux is convergent or divergent:

children.html: ∂u∂t=−∂F∂x\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = - \frac{\partial F}{\partial x}∂t∂u​=−∂x∂F​

children.value: Putting this together gives the classical diffusion equation in one dimension
\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \left( K \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} \right)
children.html: ∂u∂t=∂∂x(K∂u∂x)\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \left( K \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} \right)∂t∂u​=∂x∂​(K∂x∂u​)

children.value: For simplicity, we are going to limit ourselves to Cartesian geometry rather than meridional diffusion on a sphere.
We will also assume here that

children.html: KKK

children.value: is a constant, so our governing equation is

children.html: ∂u∂t=K∂2u∂x2\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = K \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2}∂t∂u​=K∂x2∂2u​

children.value: This equation represents a time-dependent diffusion process. It is an
. We want to integrate the model forward in time to model the changes in the field

children.html: u(x)u(x)u(x)

children.value: 2. Discretizing the diffusion operator in space

children.label: 2. Discretizing the diffusion operator in space

children.value: Solving a differential equation on a computer always requires some approximation to represent the continuous function

children.html: u(x,t)u(x,t)u(x,t)

children.value: and its derivatives in terms of discrete quantities (arrays of numbers).
We have already dealt with simple discretization of the time derivative back in [Lecture 2](./Lecture02 -- Solving the zero-dimensional
method to step all our of radiation models forward in time so far.

children.html: u(x,t)u(x,t)u(x,t)

children.label: Some notation for discretization of u(x,t)

children.value: We will discretize time and space on grids

children.html: xj,   tnx_j , ~~~ t^nxj​,   tn
ujn=u(xj, tn)u_j^n = u(x_j, ~t^n)ujn​=u(xj​, tn)

children.label: Discretizing the diffusive flux

children.value: The governing equation can be written in terms of the convergence of the diffusive flux:

children.html: ∂u∂t=−∂F∂x\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = - \frac{\partial F}{\partial x}∂t∂u​=−∂x∂F​

children.value: It is sensible to use a

children.html: ∂F∂x∣j≈Fj+12−Fj−12xj+12−xj−12\frac{\partial F}{\partial x} \bigg|_j \approx \frac{F_{j+\frac{1}{2}} - F_{j-\frac{1}{2}}}{x_{j+\frac{1}{2}} - x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}}∂x∂F​∣∣​j​≈xj+21​​−xj−21​​Fj+21​​−Fj−21​​​
xjx_jxj​

∂u∂t∣j≈−Fj+12−Fj−12xj+12−xj−12\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_j \approx - \frac{F_{j+\frac{1}{2}} - F_{j-\frac{1}{2}}}{x_{j+\frac{1}{2}} - x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}}∂t∂u​∣∣​j​≈−xj+21​​−xj−21​​Fj+21​​−Fj−21​​​

children.value: The flux itself depends on a spatial derivative of

children.html: uuu

children.value: . We will apply the same centered difference approximation. At point

children.html: xjx_jxj​
∂u∂x≈uj+12−uj−12xj+12−xj−12\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} \approx \frac{u_{j+\frac{1}{2}} - u_{j-\frac{1}{2}}}{x_{j+\frac{1}{2}} - x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}}∂x∂u​≈xj+21​​−xj−21​​uj+21​​−uj−21​​​

children.value: But we actually want to approximate

children.html: Fj+12F_{j+\frac{1}{2}}Fj+21​​
Fj−12F_{j-\frac{1}{2}}Fj−21​​

children.value: , so we apply the centered difference formula at these intermediate points to get

children.html: Fj+12≈−Kuj+1−ujxj+1−xjF_{j+\frac{1}{2}} \approx -K \frac{u_{j+1} - u_{j}}{x_{j+1} - x_{j}}Fj+21​​≈−Kxj+1​−xj​uj+1​−uj​​
Fj−12≈−Kuj−uj−1xj−xj−1F_{j-\frac{1}{2}} \approx -K \frac{u_{j} - u_{j-1}}{x_{j} - x_{j-1}}Fj−21​​≈−Kxj​−xj−1​uj​−uj−1​​

children.value: Putting this all together, we can write the time tendency at

children.html: xjx_jxj​

children.value: \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_j  \approx K \frac{ \frac{u_{j+1} - u_{j}}{x_{j+1} - x_{j}} - \frac{u_{j} - u_{j-1}}{x_{j} - x_{j-1}}}{x_{j+\frac{1}{2}} - x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}}
children.html: ∂u∂t∣j≈Kuj+1−ujxj+1−xj−uj−uj−1xj−xj−1xj+12−xj−12\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_j \approx K \frac{ \frac{u_{j+1} - u_{j}}{x_{j+1} - x_{j}} - \frac{u_{j} - u_{j-1}}{x_{j} - x_{j-1}}}{x_{j+\frac{1}{2}} - x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}}∂t∂u​∣∣​j​≈Kxj+21​​−xj−21​​xj+1​−xj​uj+1​−uj​​−xj​−xj−1​uj​−uj−1​​​

children.value: We’ll make things easy on ourselves by using uniform grid spacing in

children.html: xxx
xj+1−xj=xj−xj−1=xj+12−xj−12=Δxx_{j+1} - x_{j} = x_{j} - x_{j-1} = x_{j+\frac{1}{2}} - x_{j-\frac{1}{2}} = \Delta xxj+1​−xj​=xj​−xj−1​=xj+21​​−xj−21​​=Δx

children.value: So our final formula for the diffusive flux convergence is
\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_j  \approx K \frac{ u_{j+1} - 2 u_{j} + u_{j-1}}{\Delta x^2}
children.html: ∂u∂t∣j≈Kuj+1−2uj+uj−1Δx2\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_j \approx K \frac{ u_{j+1} - 2 u_{j} + u_{j-1}}{\Delta x^2}∂t∂u​∣∣​j​≈KΔx2uj+1​−2uj​+uj−1​​

children.label: No-flux boundary conditions

children.html: 0≤x≤10 \le x \le 10≤x≤1
x=0,1x=0, 1x=0,1

children.value: The physical boundary condition at the walls is that there can be no flux in or out of the walls:

children.html: F(0)=F(1)=0F(0) = F(1) = 0F(0)=F(1)=0
uuu
∂u∂x=0   at   x=0,1\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} = 0 ~~~ \text{at} ~~~ x=0,1∂x∂u​=0   at   x=0,1

children.label: The staggered grid

children.value: Suppose we have a grid of

children.html: J+1J+1J+1
x=0x=0x=0
x=1x=1x=1
x0∗=0x^*_0 = 0 x0∗​=0
x1∗=Δxx^*_1 = \Delta xx1∗​=Δx
x2∗=2 Δxx^*_2 = 2~\Delta xx2∗​=2 Δx
xj∗=j Δxx^*_j = j~\Delta xxj∗​=j Δx
xJ−1∗=(J−1) Δx=1−Δxx^*_{J-1} = (J-1)~\Delta x = 1 - \Delta x xJ−1∗​=(J−1) Δx=1−Δx
xJ∗=J Δx=1x^*_J = J ~ \Delta x = 1 xJ∗​=J Δx=1

children.value: Clearly then the grid spacing must be

children.html: Δx=1/J\Delta x = 1/JΔx=1/J

children.value: We’ll define the fluxes on this grid. The boundary conditions can thus be written

children.html: F0=FJ=0F_0 = F_J = 0F0​=FJ​=0

uuu

children.value: from the wall, and there are a total of

children.html: JJJ
x0=Δx/2x_0 = \Delta x / 2x0​=Δx/2
x1=Δx/2+Δxx_1 = \Delta x / 2 + \Delta xx1​=Δx/2+Δx
x2=Δx/2+2 Δxx_2 = \Delta x / 2 + 2~\Delta xx2​=Δx/2+2 Δx
xj=Δx/2+j Δxx_j = \Delta x / 2 + j~\Delta xxj​=Δx/2+j Δx
xJ−1=Δx/2+(J−1) Δx=1−Δx/2x_{J-1} = \Delta x / 2 + (J-1)~\Delta x = 1 - \Delta x / 2 xJ−1​=Δx/2+(J−1) Δx=1−Δx/2

children.value: Implementing the boundary condition on the staggered grid

children.label: Implementing the boundary condition on the staggered grid

children.html: x0x_0x0​
∂u∂t∣0≈−F1−F0Δx\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_0 \approx -\frac{ F_1 - F_0}{\Delta x}∂t∂u​∣∣​0​≈−ΔxF1​−F0​​
F0=0F_0 = 0F0​=0
F1F_1F1​

children.value: \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_0  \approx K \frac{ u_1 - u_0 }{\Delta x^2}
children.html: ∂u∂t∣0≈Ku1−u0Δx2\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_0 \approx K \frac{ u_1 - u_0 }{\Delta x^2}∂t∂u​∣∣​0​≈KΔx2u1​−u0​​

children.value: The same procedure at the other wall yields
\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_{J-1}  \approx - K \frac{ u_{J-1} - u_{J-2} }{\Delta x^2}
children.html: ∂u∂t∣J−1≈−KuJ−1−uJ−2Δx2\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_{J-1} \approx - K \frac{ u_{J-1} - u_{J-2} }{\Delta x^2}∂t∂u​∣∣​J−1​≈−KΔx2uJ−1​−uJ−2​​

children.value: Pulling this all together we have a complete discretization of the diffusion operator including its boundary conditions:
\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_0  \approx K \frac{ u_1 - u_0 }{\Delta x^2}
children.html: ∂u∂t∣0≈Ku1−u0Δx2\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_0 \approx K \frac{ u_1 - u_0 }{\Delta x^2}∂t∂u​∣∣​0​≈KΔx2u1​−u0​​

children.value: \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_j  \approx K \frac{ u_{j+1} - 2 u_{j} + u_{j-1}}{\Delta x^2}, ~~~~~~ j=1,...,J-2
children.html: ∂u∂t∣j≈Kuj+1−2uj+uj−1Δx2,      j=1,...,J−2\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_j \approx K \frac{ u_{j+1} - 2 u_{j} + u_{j-1}}{\Delta x^2}, ~~~~~~ j=1,...,J-2∂t∂u​∣∣​j​≈KΔx2uj+1​−2uj​+uj−1​​,      j=1,...,J−2

children.value: \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_{J-1}  \approx - K \frac{ u_{J-1} - u_{J-2} }{\Delta x^2}
children.html: ∂u∂t∣J−1≈−KuJ−1−uJ−2Δx2\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \bigg|_{J-1} \approx - K \frac{ u_{J-1} - u_{J-2} }{\Delta x^2}∂t∂u​∣∣​J−1​≈−KΔx2uJ−1​−uJ−2​​

children.value: 3. Coding the discretized diffusion operator in

children.label: 3. Coding the discretized diffusion operator in numpy

children.value:
%matplotlib inline
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from IPython.display import display, Math, Latex
Here we will divide our domain up into 20 grid points.

J1 = 20
J = J1
deltax = 1./J
display(Math(r'J = %i' %J))
display(Math(r'\Delta x = %0.3f' %deltax))
The fluxes will be solved on the staggered grid with 21 points.

children.html: uuu

children.value: will be solved on the 20 point grid.

xstag = np.linspace(0., 1., J+1)
x = xstag[:-1] + deltax/2
print( x)
Here’s one way to implement the finite difference, using array indexing.
We can also use the function

data.name: stdout
data.text:
Help on _ArrayFunctionDispatcher in module numpy:

diff(a, n=1, axis=-1, prepend=<no value>, append=<no value>)
    Calculate the n-th discrete difference along the given axis.

    The first difference is given by ``out[i] = a[i+1] - a[i]`` along
    the given axis, higher differences are calculated by using `diff`
    recursively.

    Parameters
    ----------
    a : array_like
        Input array
    n : int, optional
        The number of times values are differenced. If zero, the input
        is returned as-is.
    axis : int, optional
        The axis along which the difference is taken, default is the
        last axis.
    prepend, append : array_like, optional
        Values to prepend or append to `a` along axis prior to
        performing the difference.  Scalar values are expanded to
        arrays with length 1 in the direction of axis and the shape
        of the input array in along all other axes.  Otherwise the
        dimension and shape must match `a` except along axis.

        .. versionadded:: 1.16.0

    Returns
    -------
    diff : ndarray
        The n-th differences. The shape of the output is the same as `a`
        except along `axis` where the dimension is smaller by `n`. The
        type of the output is the same as the type of the difference
        between any two elements of `a`. This is the same as the type of
        `a` in most cases. A notable exception is `datetime64`, which
        results in a `timedelta64` output array.

    See Also
    --------
    gradient, ediff1d, cumsum

    Notes
    -----
    Type is preserved for boolean arrays, so the result will contain
    `False` when consecutive elements are the same and `True` when they
    differ.

    For unsigned integer arrays, the results will also be unsigned. This
    should not be surprising, as the result is consistent with
    calculating the difference directly:

    >>> u8_arr = np.array([1, 0], dtype=np.uint8)
    >>> np.diff(u8_arr)
    array([255], dtype=uint8)
    >>> u8_arr[1,...] - u8_arr[0,...]
    255

    If this is not desirable, then the array should be cast to a larger
    integer type first:

    >>> i16_arr = u8_arr.astype(np.int16)
    >>> np.diff(i16_arr)
    array([-1], dtype=int16)

    Examples
    --------
    >>> import numpy as np
    >>> x = np.array([1, 2, 4, 7, 0])
    >>> np.diff(x)
    array([ 1,  2,  3, -7])
    >>> np.diff(x, n=2)
    array([  1,   1, -10])

    >>> x = np.array([[1, 3, 6, 10], [0, 5, 6, 8]])
    >>> np.diff(x)
    array([[2, 3, 4],
           [5, 1, 2]])
    >>> np.diff(x, axis=0)
    array([[-1,  2,  0, -2]])

    >>> x = np.arange('1066-10-13', '1066-10-16', dtype=np.datetime64)
    >>> np.diff(x)
    array([1, 1], dtype='timedelta64[D]')

children.value: Here is a function that computes the diffusive flux

children.html: FFF

children.value: on the staggered grid, including the boundaries.

def diffusive_flux(u, deltax, K=1):
    #  Take the finite difference
    F = np.diff(u)/deltax
    #  add a zero as the first element (no flux on boundary)
    F = np.insert(F, 0, 0.)
    #  add another zero as the last element (no flux on boundary)
    F = np.append(F, 0.)
    #  flux is DOWN gradient, proportional to D
    return -K*F

children.html: uuu

children.value: is just the convergence of this flux, which requires one more finite difference:

def diffusion(u, deltax, K=1):
    #  compute flux
    F = diffusive_flux(u, deltax, K)
    #  take convergence of flux
    return -np.diff(F) / deltax

children.label: A smooth example

children.html: uuu

children.value: field that has a local maximum in the interior.
The gaussian (bell curve) function is a convenient way to create such a field.

K = 0.01
u = gaussian(x, 0.5, 0.08)
dudt = diffusion(u, deltax, K=K)
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1)
ax.plot(x, u, label='$u(x)$')
ax.plot(x, dudt, label='$du/dt$')
ax.legend()
Hopefully this makes sense. The diffusion is acting to smooth out

children.html: uuu

children.value: by reducing the peak and increasing

children.html: uuu

children.value: on the flanks of the gaussian bump.

children.label: Some non-smooth examples

children.value: Use a random number generator to create some noisy initial conditions.

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10,8))
for n in range(4):
    u = np.random.random(J)
    dudt = diffusion(u, deltax, K)
    ax = fig.add_subplot(2,2,n+1)
    ax.plot(x, u)
    ax.plot(x, dudt)

children.label: 4. Discretizing the time derivative

children.value: The simplest way to discretize the time derivative is the

children.html: dudt∣n≈un+1−unΔt\frac{d u}{dt} \bigg|^n \approx \frac{u^{n+1} - u^n}{\Delta t}dtdu​∣∣​n≈Δtun+1−un​

children.value: We have already used this method to step our prognostic variables forward in time.
Solving the above for the future value of

children.html: uuu
un+1=un+Δtdudt∣nu^{n+1} = u^n + \Delta t \frac{d u}{dt} \bigg|^nun+1=un+Δtdtdu​∣∣​n

children.value: We apply our discretization of the diffusion operator to the current value of the field

children.html: ujnu^n_jujn​

children.value: , to get our formula for the future values:
u_j^{n+1} = u_j^n + \frac{K \Delta t}{\Delta x^2} \left( u^n_{j+1} - 2 u^n_{j} + u^n_{j-1} \right)
children.html: ujn+1=ujn+KΔtΔx2(uj+1n−2ujn+uj−1n)u_j^{n+1} = u_j^n + \frac{K \Delta t}{\Delta x^2} \left( u^n_{j+1} - 2 u^n_{j} + u^n_{j-1} \right)ujn+1​=ujn​+Δx2KΔt​(uj+1n​−2ujn​+uj−1n​)

children.value: (except at the boundaries, where the diffusion operator is slightly different -- see above).
Together, this scheme is known as
It is very simple to implement in

K = 0.01
deltat = 0.125
deltat1 = deltat

u0 = gaussian(x, 0.5, 0.08)
u1 = step_forward(u0, deltax, deltat1, K)
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1)
ax.plot(x, u0, label='initial')
ax.plot(x, u1, label='next')
ax.legend()
Let’s loop through a number of timesteps.

#  regular resolution
J = 20
deltax = 1./J
xstag = np.linspace(0., 1., J+1)
x = xstag[:-1] + deltax/2

u = gaussian(x, 0.5, 0.08)
niter = 11
for n in range(niter):
    u = step_forward(u, deltax, deltat1, K)
    plt.plot(x, u, label=n)
plt.legend()
The numerics were easy to implement, and the scheme seems to work very well! The results are physically sensible.
Now, suppose that you wanted to

children.label: Now, suppose that you wanted to double the spatial resolution

children.html: J=40J=40J=40

children.value:
#  double the resolution
scaling_factor = 2
J = J1 * scaling_factor
deltax = 1./J
xstag = np.linspace(0., 1., J+1)
x = xstag[:-1] + deltax/2

u = gaussian(x, 0.5, 0.08)
for n in range(niter):
    u = step_forward(u, deltax, deltat1, K)
    plt.plot(x, u, label=n)
plt.legend()
Suddenly our scheme is producing numerical noise that grows in time and overwhelms to smooth physical solution we are trying to model.
What went wrong, and what can we do about it?
5. Stability analysis of the FTCS scheme

children.label: 5. Stability analysis of the FTCS scheme
numericalrecipesC

children.value: Numerical Recipes in C: The Art of Scientific Computing
This is an example of the so-called
We look for normal mode solutions (i.e. wavy sines and cosines) of the finite difference equations of the form

children.html: ujn=ξnexp⁡(i k j Δx)u_j^n = \xi^n \exp(i~k~j~ \Delta x)ujn​=ξnexp(i k j Δx)
kkk

children.value: is some real number that represents a spatial wavenumber (which can have any value), and

children.html: ξ=ξ(k)\xi = \xi(k)ξ=ξ(k)

children.value: is a complex number that depends on

children.html: kkk
ξ\xiξ
kkk

children.value: under what conditions do wavy solutions grow with time
?  (This is bad, as it means small numerical noise will become large numerical noise and make our differencing scheme unusable)
Let’s substitute the normal mode solution into our finite difference equation
\frac{u_j^{n+1} -  u_j^n}{\Delta t} = \frac{K}{\Delta x^2} \left( u^n_{j+1} - 2 u^n_{j} + u^n_{j-1} \right)
children.html: ujn+1−ujnΔt=KΔx2(uj+1n−2ujn+uj−1n)\frac{u_j^{n+1} - u_j^n}{\Delta t} = \frac{K}{\Delta x^2} \left( u^n_{j+1} - 2 u^n_{j} + u^n_{j-1} \right)Δtujn+1​−ujn​​=Δx2K​(uj+1n​−2ujn​+uj−1n​)

children.value: \frac{\xi^{n+1} \exp(i~k~j~ \Delta x) -  \xi^n \exp(i~k~j~ \Delta x)}{\Delta t} = \frac{K}{\Delta x^2} \left( \xi^n \exp(i~k~(j+1)~ \Delta x) - 2 \xi^n \exp(i~k~j~ \Delta x) + \xi^n \exp(i~k~(j-1)~ \Delta x) \right)
children.html: ξn+1exp⁡(i k j Δx)−ξnexp⁡(i k j Δx)Δt=KΔx2(ξnexp⁡(i k (j+1) Δx)−2ξnexp⁡(i k j Δx)+ξnexp⁡(i k (j−1) Δx))\frac{\xi^{n+1} \exp(i~k~j~ \Delta x) - \xi^n \exp(i~k~j~ \Delta x)}{\Delta t} = \frac{K}{\Delta x^2} \left( \xi^n \exp(i~k~(j+1)~ \Delta x) - 2 \xi^n \exp(i~k~j~ \Delta x) + \xi^n \exp(i~k~(j-1)~ \Delta x) \right)Δtξn+1exp(i k j Δx)−ξnexp(i k j Δx)​=Δx2K​(ξnexp(i k (j+1) Δx)−2ξnexp(i k j Δx)+ξnexp(i k (j−1) Δx))
ξnexp⁡(i k j Δx)\xi^n \exp(i~k~j~\Delta x)ξnexp(i k j Δx)

ξn+1ξn−1=KΔtΔx2(exp⁡(i k Δx)−2+exp⁡(−i k Δx))\frac{\xi^{n+1}}{\xi^n} - 1 = \frac{K \Delta t}{\Delta x^2} \left(\exp(i~k~\Delta x) - 2 + \exp(-i~k~\Delta x) \right)ξnξn+1​−1=Δx2KΔt​(exp(i k Δx)−2+exp(−i k Δx))
ξn+1ξn=1+KΔtΔx2(2cos⁡(k Δx)−2)\frac{\xi^{n+1}}{\xi^n} = 1 + \frac{K \Delta t}{\Delta x^2} \left(2 \cos(k~\Delta x) - 2 \right)ξnξn+1​=1+Δx2KΔt​(2cos(k Δx)−2)

children.value: Or using a double angle identity,

children.html: ξn+1ξn=1−4KΔtΔx2sin⁡2(k Δx2)\frac{\xi^{n+1}}{\xi^n} = 1 - \frac{4 K \Delta t}{\Delta x^2} \sin^2 \left( \frac{k~\Delta x}{2} \right)ξnξn+1​=1−Δx24KΔt​sin2(2k Δx​)

children.value: The wavy solution must not grow with time

children.label: The wavy solution must not grow with time

children.value: We need to prevent growing normal modes. So successive amplitudes should be

children.html: ∣ξn+1ξn∣≤1\bigg| \frac{\xi^{n+1}}{\xi^n} \bigg| \le 1∣∣​ξnξn+1​∣∣​≤1
∣1−4KΔtΔx2sin⁡2(k Δx2)∣≤1\bigg| 1 - \frac{4 K \Delta t}{\Delta x^2} \sin^2 \left( \frac{k~\Delta x}{2} \right) \bigg| \le 1∣∣​1−Δx24KΔt​sin2(2k Δx​)∣∣​≤1

children.value: and this condition must be met for

children.html: kkk
0≤sin⁡2(ϕ)≤10 \le \sin^2(\phi) \le 10≤sin2(ϕ)≤1
ϕ\phiϕ

children.value: , our condition can only be violated if

children.html: 4KΔtΔx2>2\frac{4 K \Delta t}{\Delta x^2} > 2Δx24KΔt​>2

children.value: We conclude the the FTCS scheme is stable so long as this stability condition is met:

children.html: Δt≤Δx22K\Delta t \le \frac{\Delta x^2}{2 K}Δt≤2KΔx2​

children.value: We have just discovered an important constraint on the allowable timestep

children.label: We have just discovered an important constraint on the allowable timestep

children.value: The maximum timestep we can use with the FTCS scheme for the diffusion equation is proportional to

children.html: Δx2\Delta x^2Δx2

children.value: A doubling of the spatial resolution would require a 4x shorter timestep to preserve numerical stability.
Physically, the restriction is that the maximum allowable timestep is approximately the diffusion time across a grid cell of width

children.html: Δx\Delta xΔx

children.value: 6. Numerical tests with a shorter timestep

children.label: 6. Numerical tests with a shorter timestep

children.value: Going back to our Gaussian example, let’s double the resolution but shorten the timestep by a factor of 4.

#  double the resolution
J = J1 * scaling_factor
deltax = 1./J
xstag = np.linspace(0., 1., J+1)
x = xstag[:-1] + deltax/2

K = 0.01
#  The maximum stable timestep
deltat_max = deltax**2 / 2 / K
print( 'The maximum allowable timestep is %f' %deltat_max)

deltat = deltat1 / scaling_factor**2
print( '4x the previous timestep is %f' %deltat)

data.name: stdout
data.text:
The maximum allowable timestep is 0.031250
4x the previous timestep is 0.031250

children.value: Success! The graph now looks like a smoother (higher resolution) version of our first integration with the coarser grid.
:  our calculation required 4 times more timesteps to do the same integration.
The total increase in computational cost was actally a factor of 8 to get a factor of 2 increase in spatial resolution.
7. The need for a more efficient method

children.label: 7. The need for a more efficient method

children.html: Δt≤Δx22K\Delta t \le \frac{\Delta x^2}{2 K}Δt≤2KΔx2​

children.value: is often too restrictive to be practical!
. Suppose we want a spatial resolution of 1º latitude. Then we have 180 grid points from pole to pole, and our physical length scale is

children.html: Δx≈105m\Delta x \approx 10^5 \text{m}Δx≈105m

children.value: We were using a diffusivity of

children.html: D=0.6 W m−2 K−1D = 0.6 ~ \text{W m}^{-2}~\text{K}^{-1}D=0.6 W m−2 K−1
C=4×107 J m−2 K−1C = 4 \times 10^7 ~ \text{J m}^{-2} ~\text{K}^{-1}C=4×107 J m−2 K−1

children.value: Accounting for the spherical geometry in our

children.html: K=2πa2DC=2π (6.4×106 m)2 (0.6 W m−2 K−1)4×107 J m−2 K−1≈4×106 m2 s−1K = \frac{2 \pi a^2 D}{C} = \frac{2 \pi ~ (6.4 \times 10^6 ~\text{m})^2 ~(0.6 ~ \text{W m}^{-2}~\text{K}^{-1})}{4 \times 10^7 ~ \text{J m}^{-2} ~\text{K}^{-1}} \approx 4 \times 10^{6} ~ \text{m}^2 ~ \text{s}^{-1}K=C2πa2D​=4×107 J m−2 K−12π (6.4×106 m)2 (0.6 W m−2 K−1)​≈4×106 m2 s−1

children.value: Recall that this is the diffusivity associated with the large-scale motion of the atmosphere (mostly). If we take a typical velocity scale for a mid-latitude eddy,

children.html: V≈20 m s−1V \approx 20~\text{m s}^{-1}V≈20 m s−1

children.value: , and a typical length scale for that eddy,

children.html: L≈2000 kmL \approx 2000~\text{km}L≈2000 km
K=V L=4×106 m2 s−1K = V~ L = 4 \times 10^{6} ~ \text{m}^2 ~ \text{s}^{-1}K=V L=4×106 m2 s−1

children.value: Using these numbers the stability condition is roughly

children.html: Δt≤103 s\Delta t \le 10^3 ~\text{s}Δt≤103 s

children.value: which is less than one hour!
And if we wanted to double the resolution to 0.5º, we would need a timestep of just a few minutes.
This can be a very onerous requirement for a model that would like to integrate out for many years.
We can do better, but we need a different time discretization!

children.label: 8. Implicit time method

children.value: With numerical methods for partial differential equations, it often turns out that a small change in the discretization can make an enormous difference in the results.
scheme applies exactly the same centered difference scheme to the spatial derivatives in the diffusion operator.
But instead of applying the operator to the field

children.html: unu^nun
nnn

children.value: , we instead apply it to the field

children.html: un+1u^{n+1}un+1

children.value: \frac{u_j^{n+1} - u_j^n}{\Delta t} =  \frac{K}{\Delta x^2} \left( u^{n+1}_{j+1} - 2 u^{n+1}_{j} + u^{n+1}_{j-1} \right)
children.html: ujn+1−ujnΔt=KΔx2(uj+1n+1−2ujn+1+uj−1n+1)\frac{u_j^{n+1} - u_j^n}{\Delta t} = \frac{K}{\Delta x^2} \left( u^{n+1}_{j+1} - 2 u^{n+1}_{j} + u^{n+1}_{j-1} \right)Δtujn+1​−ujn​​=Δx2K​(uj+1n+1​−2ujn+1​+uj−1n+1​)

children.value: in the interior, and at the boundaries:

children.html: u0n+1−u0nΔt=KΔx2(u1n+1−u0n+1)\frac{u_0^{n+1} - u_0^n}{\Delta t} = \frac{K}{\Delta x^2} \left( u^{n+1}_1 - u^{n+1}_0 \right)Δtu0n+1​−u0n​​=Δx2K​(u1n+1​−u0n+1​)
uJ−1n+1−uJ−1nΔt=−KΔx2(uJ−1n+1−uJ−2n+1)\frac{u_{J-1}^{n+1} - u_{J-1}^n}{\Delta t} = - \frac{K}{\Delta x^2} \left( u_{J-1}^{n+1} - u_{J-2}^{n+1} \right)ΔtuJ−1n+1​−uJ−1n​​=−Δx2K​(uJ−1n+1​−uJ−2n+1​)

children.value: This might seem like a strange way to write the system, since
we don’t know the future state of the system at

children.html: tn+1t^{n+1}tn+1

children.value: . That’s what we’re trying to solve for!
Let’s move all terms evaluated at

children.html: tn+1t^{n+1}tn+1

children.value: u_j^{n+1}  - \frac{K \Delta t}{\Delta x^2} \left( u^{n+1}_{j+1} - 2 u^{n+1}_{j} + u^{n+1}_{j-1} \right) = u_j^n
children.html: ujn+1−KΔtΔx2(uj+1n+1−2ujn+1+uj−1n+1)=ujnu_j^{n+1} - \frac{K \Delta t}{\Delta x^2} \left( u^{n+1}_{j+1} - 2 u^{n+1}_{j} + u^{n+1}_{j-1} \right) = u_j^nujn+1​−Δx2KΔt​(uj+1n+1​−2ujn+1​+uj−1n+1​)=ujn​
−K∗uj+1n+1+(1+2K∗)ujn+1−K∗uj−1n+1=ujn-K^* u^{n+1}_{j+1} + \left(1+2K^* \right) u_j^{n+1} - K^* u_{j-1}^{n+1} = u_j^n−K∗uj+1n+1​+(1+2K∗)ujn+1​−K∗uj−1n+1​=ujn​

children.value: where we have introduced a non-dimensional diffusivity

children.html: K∗=KΔtΔx2K^* = \frac{K \Delta t}{\Delta x^2}K∗=Δx2KΔt​

children.value: The implicit scheme as a matrix problem

children.label: The implicit scheme as a matrix problem

children.value: We can write this as a matrix equation

U\mathbf{U}U

u(x)u(x)u(x)

Un+1\mathbf{U}^{n+1}Un+1

A=[1+K∗−K∗00...000−K∗1+2K∗−K∗0...0000−K∗1+2K∗−K∗...000........................0000...−K∗1+2K∗−K∗0000...0−K∗1+K∗]\mathbf{A} = \left[ \begin{array}{cccccccc} 1+K^* & -K^* & 0 & 0 & ... & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ -K^* & 1+2K^* & -K^* & 0 & ... & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -K^* & 1+2K^* & -K^* &... & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ ... & ... & ... & ... & ... & ... & ... & ... \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & ... & -K^* & 1+2K^* & -K^* \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & ... & 0 & -K^* & 1+K^* \\ \end{array} \right]A=⎣⎡​1+K∗−K∗0...00​−K∗1+2K∗−K∗...00​0−K∗1+2K∗...00​00−K∗...00​..................​000...−K∗0​000...1+2K∗−K∗​000...−K∗1+K∗​⎦⎤​

children.value: Solving for the future state of the system

children.html: Un+1\mathbf{U}^{n+1}Un+1

children.value: is then just the solution of the linear system

children.html: Un+1=A−1Un\mathbf{U}^{n+1} = \mathbf{A}^{-1} \mathbf{U}^{n}Un+1=A−1Un

children.value: Solving a tridiagonal matrix problem like this is a very common operation in computer science, and efficient numerical routines are available in many languages (including Python /
Stability analysis of the implicit scheme

children.label: Stability analysis of the implicit scheme

children.value: We’ll skip the details, but the amplification factor for this scheme is (see
book or other text on numerical methods):

children.html: ξn+1ξn=11+4K∗sin⁡2(kΔx2)\frac{\xi^{n+1}}{\xi^n} = \frac{1}{1+4 K^* \sin^2 \left( \frac{k \Delta x}{2} \right) }ξnξn+1​=1+4K∗sin2(2kΔx​)1​
∣ξn+1ξn∣≤1\bigg| \frac{\xi^{n+1}}{\xi^n} \bigg| \le 1∣∣​ξnξn+1​∣∣​≤1

children.value: is met for any value of

Δt\Delta tΔt

children.value: ) is unconditionally stable for any choice of timestep.

children.label: 9. Your homework assignment

children.value: Write Python code to solve the diffusion equation using this implicit time method. Demonstrate that it is numerically stable for much larger timesteps than we were able to use with the forward-time method. One way to do this is to use a much higher spatial resolution.

children.label: Some final thoughts:

children.value: We have just scratched the surface of the wonders and sorrows of numerical methods here. The implicit method is very
method for a diffusion problem, particularly when you are interested in some of the faster dynamics of the system (as opposed to just getting the system quickly to its equilibrium state).
There are always trade-offs in the choice of a numerical method.
The equations for most climate models are sufficiently complex that more than one numerical method is necessary. Even in the simple diffusive
, the radiation terms are handled by a forward-time method while the diffusion term is solved implicitly.
Once you have worked through the above problem (diffusion only), you might want to look in the
code to see how the diffusion solver is implemented there, and how it is used when you integrate the
